author: {'steamid': '76561198052302937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1411500574}
review:
Суть игры состоит в том, чтобы узнать, что же произошло с женой (или девушкой - кто его знает, кем она ему приходится) главного героя 20 лет назад. Для этого он приезжает на их место отдыха - Pineview Drive, где, собственно, и пропала Линда (имя пропавшей). Нам надо прожить 30 дней в этом особняке и раскрыть тайну исчезновения.
Признаюсь честно, поначалу игра понравилась: звуковое сопровождение (музыка, шорохи в доме и др.), таинственность и исследовательский элемент были неплохи. Ближе к середине игры (на день 12-13) исследовать сособняк на наличие ключей для закрытых дверей уже надоедало. Происходит "бу"-момент - получаете ключ- ищете нужную дверь- читаете записку - день окончен-profit!. И так все 30 дней.
Последний же день убил наповал. Ничего в итоге не разъясняется, куда пропала Линда, что с нами стало: просто остается вопрос: "Что это было?" Только после прочтения комментариев разработчиков насчет концовки становится ясно, что же они имели в виду. Я непротив, чтобы в игре, тем более такого жанра, оставалась некая недосказанность, но не настолько, чтобы никто ничего не понял в итоге. 
У меня создалось впечатление, что под конец игры у разработчиков просто не осталось средств и идей, и они уже по-быстрому напихали элементы из своих, видимо, ранних заготовок к другому проекту и также по-быстрому все завершили. 
И как итог - я была разочарована, так как ожидала большего. 
Разработчикам желаю удачи в следующих проектах, поскольку видно, что создавать атмосферу напряженности и жути они умеют. Просто подкачал сюжет и геймплей, который навевал уныние уже с середины игры.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121513274', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1252, 'last_played': 1412187162}
review:
Pineview Drive — это единственный в своем роде хоррор, который знает все о вашем страхе.

Старый и заброшенный особняк расположен в самом конце местечка под названием Pineview Drive. Беспокойный мужчина стоит у ворот и тщательно разглядывает собственность. 20 лет назад он посетил это имение вместе со своей женой Линдой. Во время их пребывания возлюбленная исчезла без следа, а ее таинственное исчезновение так и осталось нераскрытым.

За 20 лет — ни единой зацепки. Все эти годы герой жил в постоянном напряжении и держался подальше от этого дома. Но сейчас он все-таки решил вернуться сюда и попытаться смириться со своим кошмарным прошлым.

Зловещие легенды, преследующие этот приморский домик, стали широко известны. Истории гласят о том, что никто не сумел продержаться в особняке больше 30 дней с тех пор, как исчезла Линда. Вам предстоит столкнуться с силой, куда более могущественной, чем вы могли себе представить. Вы должны пересечь порог и противостоять злу, окутавшему этот загадочный дом. Для того, чтобы распутать тайну исчезновения Линды и положить конец всей этой истории, нельзя тратить ни минуты.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130228562', 'num_games_owned': 51, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 744, 'last_played': 1664555043}
review:
Das Spiel ist von überzeugender Grafik und erstklassiger Grusel - Atmosphäre. Ohne Blutbad und Ekelbilder wird immer wieder für Gänsehaut gesorgt. Das Haus ist hervorragend gestaltet. Alles ist stimmig und passend. Die Garderoben, die Wandbilder, die Beleuchtung. Man riecht förmlich das alte Holz der knarzenden Treppen.
Jedoch wird es über die vielen Level dann doch manchmal etwas fade: Schlüssel suchen. Dann die Tür suchen, die zu dem Schlüssel passt, dann den Brief finden. Dies zieht sich über die meisten Tage  (Level) des Spiels und sollte etwas häufiger durch andere Aufgaben und/oder Ereignisse unterbrochen werden, z-B. ähnlich wie in Tag 30. 
Aber es lohnt sich dranzubleiben. Die Gruseleffekte nehmen zu und legen auch an Qualität zu. Die Schattenspiele sind einzigartig.
Die Horror-Atmosphäre stützt sich zum grössten Teil auf Soundeffekte. Auch wenn man es erst nicht glauben mag, aber es wurde so brilliant umgesetzt, dass es funktioniert. 
Da man im Laufe des Spiels das Haus Zimmer für Zimmer, Korridor für Korridor, Trackt für Trackt erforscht, wird es mit der Zeit unübersichtlich und man kann sich verlaufen. Jedoch wird es nicht so übertrieben schlimm, dass man nur noch umherirrt. Es ist also noch zu schaffen, einen ungefähren Überblick zu behalten.
Fazit: Tolles Spiel mit Grusel ohne Blutbad und Gewalt. Auch wenn man im Mittel etwas durchhalten muss und dranbleiben muss: Es lohnt sich. Prädikat: Empfehlenswert.
Letsplayer: Es ist darauf zu achten, dass die Zuschauer die Soundatmosphäre mitbekommen und das Spiel sollte nicht übermoderiert, also plattgequatscht werden.
2. September 2014 - Julia LetsPlays

author: {'steamid': '76561198012160076', 'num_games_owned': 1317, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1408799624}
review:
びっくりさせてくる系のホラーゲームで、30日間同じ洋館で生活する。
ホラーゲームとしてはそこまで怖い部類ではない。

基本的に、「鍵を見つけてその鍵で開けることのできる部屋を探す」という事を30日間繰り返す。
ヒントは毎日ランダムなタイミングで数秒間字幕として表示されるのみなので、英文が理解できないor読みきれなかった時点で全ての部屋を回らなければいけなくなる。
だが、SAN値みたいなのがあり、探索中に起こる怪奇現象でそれがなくなるとゲームオーバーになり、その日の最初からになる。

これを買うなら他のホラゲ買った方がいい

author: {'steamid': '76561198055239323', 'num_games_owned': 1201, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1581787701}
review:
Durch ein kleines LetsPlay und durch einen Steamfreund sowies einem kleinen Artikel wo drin stand, das das Spiel auf den Spieler reagiert, also seine Aktionen usw und somit Gruseliger wird, bin ich hellhörig geworden!

Ja ich ahbe "nur" knapp 2 st mit dem Spiel verbracht, habe es gestreamed und somit die 2st durchgezogen bis tag 6!

Am Titelbildschirm angekommen war ich noch sehr angetan da selbst dieser einen kleinen Schockeffekt beinhaltet! Die Idee an sich fande ich auch klasse und musste es einfach haben in der Hoffnung das ich mich auch mal wieder erschrecken würde! Ich bin anscheinend sauviel gewohnt denn nach den ersten 1-2 Scares war bei mir der Ofen fast aus! Die Schocks sind an für sich relativ originelö (hat man aber schon in vielen Filmen gesehen) und diese schocken einfach nach gewisser zeit kaum noch! Es kommen immerwieder die selben Sounds, geräusche etc! Wie egsagt, das alles ist super ghemacht und Athmosphärisch aber verfehlt zumindest bei mir jetzt schon die Wirkung! Spoilern möchte ich nicht weiter denn jetzt kommt der größte Minuspunkt! das Spielprinzip!

In einem Raum aufwachen, geräusch hören, hingehen, zwischendurch ein paar Schritte und Kinderlachen, Schlüssel Finden, Licht an, Schlüssel finden, Licht aus, Schlüssel finden, Kerzen an, Schlüssel finden, Kerze aus...ach und ...s
Schlüssel finden! Aber das Schlimmste ist das für jede Tür ein Schlüssel benötigt wird, das Haus wird immer Größer was die Räume angeht und man ist zu 90% nur am Rennen unm die Tür zu finden zu der der Schlüssel gehört und das nervt echt jetzt schon Tierichst! 

sehr Schade drum! Nehm es mir nicht übel, das Spiel ist nicht Schlecht, hatt aber Potenzial, ist aber nun leider schon fertig!

Leute die nix gewohnt sind und sich docvh leicht erschrecken werden sicher ihren Spaß haben, aber nicht für 20euro!

5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198009893503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1616176318}
review:
So I was looking at this game for quite a few days considering if I was gonna buy it or not, and the only thing that kept me from actually getting it was all the negative reviews that was posted on it.

I did however decide to get it and see what the game had to offer and by now I have put quite a few hours into the game. I am gonna be completely honest and neutral when I say that this game has received more thumbs down in the review section on Steam that it deserved. 

Yes the story in the game is not great and it does leave you with a lot of questions in regard to why you are staying inside a haunted house searching for your wife that went missing 20 years ago. And to be honest if I had not read the game description before playing I would never have guessed the story at all.

HOWEVER!
This game is not ment to be played for its story. The game itself has an amazing atmosphere that makes you aware of your surroundings and most of time it is not the scares, but the atmosphere itself that keeps you coming back.

Don't get me wrong, the game does have scary elements and they are VERY well placed in the game. The scares are unpredictable and suprises you every step of the way and the best of all; "The scares are awesome and not cheap!".
And not to mention that freaking ***** that makes me too scared to pass him every time a need to go through a certain hallway...

BUT BE WARNED!
The story is not the only bad thing about the game because there are quite a few other things that could definitely get improved which I will go over.

First of all as soon as I started playing this game I noticed my FPS dropped constantly between 24-34 FPS on highest quality while I was recording with my screen recorder (should probably mention that screen recorders does tend to decrease the FPS a bit when active). I did need to tinger a bit with the quality settings before i could get a 33-44 FPS.
I can play Crysis 3 with 3 times better FPS on ultra settings, and trust me, this is not a hardware problem!
My PC has a:
 - i7 4770k core processor
 - GeForce GTX 780 graphics card
 - 16GB RAM

The second issue I found with the actual gameplay itself is the objectives inside the game. A lot of people reviewing this title is calling it a "Open door simulator" and they are definitely not wrong. The entire gameplay is you finding keys so you can unlock new doors that allows you to start a new day.

But don't get discouraged, even with these faults I still believe this is a great game and if you are looking for a horror game that simulates a haunted house this is definitely a game worth getting. The whole time I was sucked into it and because of the variety of the scares I never felt each scare was remotely similar to eachother. If you are willing to go through the process of collecting keys then this game will definitely be worth it!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S8KMr1ETtKw

Nun aber zu der "Kaufempfehlung":

Das Spiel hat zwar seine Macken ist aber sehr Stimmig und Atmosphärisch. Wie ich in einigen meiner Videos schon Sagte ist einige Prozentual gehalten welches dem Spiel ermöglicht mehr Grusel Stimmung zu erhalten. (Es gibt aber auch Schlüssel Elemente die immer Gleich aufgebaut sind!)
In jedem einzelnen Tag welches man in diesem Haus beschreiten muss und davon gibt es ganze 30 an der Zahl, passiert immer was neues immer was Aufregenderes und immer was Gruseligeres.
Man sollte sich das Spiel mal selber angucken und nicht immer gleich auf Reviews zählen, denn wie Jeder von uns Gamern weiß... Ein Spiel wirkt immer anders.

Pro/Contra Liste: 

Positiv:
- Sehr gruselige bedrückende Atmosphäre 
- Gute Schockeffekt
- Grandiose Klangkulisse
- Grafik ist nicht schlecht, hätte aber auch besser sein können. Die Schatten Effekte sind aber sehr gut gemacht und auch Stimmig.


Negativ:
- Teilweise sehr Ermüdend
- Teilweise weiß man gar nicht wo man hin muss, dann ist warten angesagt bis der Protagonist dir eine Hilfe gibt, oder du musst jeden Tag aufs neue jeden schon besuchten Raum neu erkunden.. das ist teilweise sehr Nervtötend!


Wie ich schon Sagte: Das Spiel ist nicht für jeden etwas, dennoch sollte man es sich mal Angucken! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198042718931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1478145126}
review:
Auf Empfehlung eines Mitmenschen dieses Planeten und auf großzügige Spende eines anderen Menschen hin, nahm ich mir dieses Spiel zur Brust. Ich sah den Titelbildschirm. Ich war entzückt. Die Melodie, die im Hintergrund spielte, war sehr angenehm und atmosphärisch. Das Gesicht im Fenster und dieser Effekt, der den Titelbildschirm aussehen lässt wie in einem alten Film vermitteln einen guten ersten Eindruck.

Meine lieben Mitbürger und Mitbürgerinnen: Ich habe Ihnen so eben den besten Teil des Spiels, so gut ich konnte, beschrieben. Ja, Sie haben richtig gehört. Der Titelbildschirm ist das Beste, was das Spiel zu bieten hat.

Man startet das Spiel. Eine Cutscene spielt. Sie ist schelcht. Sie ist unübersichtlich. Man hat keine Ahnung, was passiert. Man steht vor einem Haus. Was tun? Man geht zum Eingang, er ist verschlossen. Was passiert? Das erste Rätsel des Spiels kommt zum Tragen. Finden sie den Schlüssel! Nun wird der gemeine Homo sapiens denken: "Oha, wo könnte dieser Schlüssel sein? Ist er vllt irgendwo in einem Gebüsch? Vllt. in einem Briefkasten?" NEIN. Sie drehen sich um 180° nach Hinten und da ist der ver ... maledeite Schlüssel. Auf dem Boden ... er lächelt sie förmlich an. Denn er weiß, dass er einer von Hunderten seiner Art ist, die Ihnen im Laufe des Spiels irgendwann förmlich aus dem Ar*ch kriechen werden. So gehen sie nun dahin und öffnen das Tor. Der Protagonist wird ihnen innerhalb von vier kurzen Sätzen seine Gedankenwelt mitteilen, die ungefähr so interessant ist wie dem Gras beim Wachsen zuzusehen. Sie werden schnell merken, dass Spiel sofort an Fahrt aufnimmt. Denn nun sehen sie sich vor der Aufgabe: "Wie komme ich denn nun in dieses Haus rein?" Sie denken sich erstmal: "Ne, der Vordereingang kann's nicht sein, das hier ist ja ein Horrorspiel, das wäre zu einfach" und so schauen sie sich vielleicht erstmal ein wenig um, werden hinter dem Haus eine Vogelscheuche bemerken, die im Laufe des Spieles einen unglaublich schlechten Job machen wird, die Krähen vom Grundstück fernzuhalten und landen letzten Endes doch beim Haupteingang. Sie versuchen diesen zu öffnen und werden mit Freuden feststellen, dass dieser verschlossen ist. "Hahah, ich hatte recht, der Haupteingang wäre zu offensichtlich gewesen" So müssen sie also nun den Schlüs .... oh warte, er ist 2 cm neben dem ve****ten sch***drecks Haupteingang. Sie betreten das Haus. Zu diesem Zeitpunkt könnte man sich noch denken, dass das Spiel gruselig werden wird. (spoiler: Pustekuchen) Sie sehen sich etwas um, merken dass alle Türen verschlossen sind, obwohl laut Aussage des Protagonisten in den letzten Jahren durchaus Leute in diesem Haus gelebt haben, aber keine Sorge, innerhalb des Hauses gibt es für jede Tür einen dazugehörigen Schlüssel, der jeweils am anderen Ende des Hauses zu finden ist. Sie laufen etwas umher, finden einen Schlüssel, probieren diesen Schlüssel an den 10 verschlossenen Türen, an denen sie schon vorbeigekommen sind aus, in eine wird er reinpassen, da finden sie einen neuen Schlüssel, den sie an den restlichen 9 Türen, die noch verbleiben ausprobieren bis sie die Richtige gefunden haben. In jenem Raum finden sie dann ... man möge es kaum glauben ... EINE TASCHENLAMPE ... und einen Schlüssel .... für eine Türe ... irgendwo ... in diesem Haus ... Nach einer Weile wird es dunkel und total creepy ... sie werden merken, sie können sich mit Hilfe der Taschenlampe, Kerzen und Lichtschaltern Lichtquellen erschaffen, die jeglichen Gesetzen der Physik widersprechen.   Sie durchsuchen also alle Räume nach Hinweisen, die der Protagonist sucht und merken nach dreimaligem Durchsuchen der Räume, dass da nix ist. Doch plötzlich nach 15 Minuten desselben Ablaufs hat sich plötzlich ein Raum geändert, Stühle stehen anders da und da ist ein Zettel. Er liest den Zettel, auf dem 5 Wörter stehen und der Tag endet.

SO UNGEFÄHR IST DANN JEDER TAG.
Ich möchte an dieser Stelle nicht viel Spoilern, ich gebe ihnen nur noch kurz meine Highlights zu diesem Spiel bekannt.

- Gleich neben dem Schlafzimmer gibt es eine Abstellkammer, die einfach mal auf alles, was sie in Physik gelernt haben, scheißt. In dieser Abstellkammer gibt es kein Fenster. Es gibt eine Lampe, die normalerweise aus ist. Es gibt absolut keine Lichtquelle, in diesem Raum, sofern man jene Lampe nicht anmacht. Wenn man in diesem Raum steht und die Türe zu ist, dann ist der Raum trotzdem vollkommen erhellt. Hat jemand dieses Spiel jemals testgespielt? Ich meine ... wie kann einem sowas nicht auffallen?

- Jeglicher Horror in diesem Spiel besteht aus billigst inszenierten Jumpscares. Mein persönlicher Favorit war recht am Anfang. Es ist ein zwei-dimensionales, kleines Jpeg, das schlichtweg, vermutlich per Paint, vergrößert wurde und dabei noch nicht mal scharf gemacht wurde. Es springen einem wortwörtlich 2D-Pixel ins Gesicht. 3spooky5me

- Jeder Tag besteht daraus: Was tun? Ich habe keinerlei Hinweis darauf, was ich wo zu tun habe. Ich laufe 10 Minuten durch die Gegend, ab und an "erschreckt" mich einer dieser legendären Jumpscares und dann entscheidet sich der Protagonist dazu, weil ihm schon so stinklangweilig von diesem Spiel wurde, einem zu sagen, wo man nachschauen sollte. Und was mich immer wieder fasziniert hat ist die Präzesion des Wissens vom Protagonisten. "Hm ... vllt. sollte ich im Badezimmer des 2. Stockwerks des Hauptrakts nachschauen, ob sich eine Möwe darin verirrt hat und gerade mit aller Urgewalt in die Badewanne abseilt." Tja und kurzer Hand entscheidet man sich dann dazu, in besagtem Badezimmer nachzusehen und siehe da: Die Möwe ist beim Versuch des Abseilens gestorben und hinterließ dabei einen Schlüssel. Und nun kommen wir zum 2. großen Gimmick dieses Spiels: Wo passt der Schlüssel? Sie haben nun den Schlüssel aus dem Darmtrakt einer Möwe entfernt und dürfen sich durch die restlichen 20000000000 Türen durchkämpfen, bis sie die Richtige gefunden haben, DIE NATÜRLICH IMMER DIE LETZTE IST, DIE SIE PROBIEREN. 

- Das Ende ist schlichtweg ... wie kann man es sagen, ohne den Entwickler so sehr zu beleidigen, als dass ich mit einer Geldstrafe rechnen müsste ... dürftig ... Es erklärt nichts ... es ist schlecht ... es ist frustierend.

Ich sitze schon eine halbe Stunde an diesem Review. Ich könnten noch 2 Stunden so weiter machen. Ich könnte jede Einzelheit aufsagen, die mit diesem Spiel nicht stimmt. Aber ich lasse es lieber, da das hier eh kein Mensch lesen wird. Ich möchte nur als Fazit sagen: 20€ für dieses Spiel sind eine absolute Unverschämtheit. Gerade mal gratis wäre dieses Spiel "ok" gewesen. Und auch nicht mehr. Der einzige Mensch, der an diesem Spiel gearbeitet hat, der sich am Ende des Tages nicht für seine Existenz schämen müsste, ist derjenige, der für den Sound verantwortlich ist. Der Sound ist okay. Die Musik ist ganz nett und die Geräusche sind halbwegs passend. 

Ich möchte eben als Vergleich das Spiel "The Cat Lady" anbringen. Für jenes Spiel war vermutlich ein wesentlich geringeres Budget vorhanden. Und trotzdem wurde mit wenig Mitteln ein kleines Meisterwerk erschaffen, das kaum Aufmerksamkeit bekommen hat und das man für 9€ auf Steam bekommen kann, während man für diese Beleidigung eines Horrorspiels 20€ berappen soll. 

Ich weiß, keiner zwingt irgendjemanden dieses Spiel zu spielen und meine Bewertung klingt wie von einem 12-jährigen, wütenden Kind geschrieben, aber für alle, die sich nicht bei jedem kleinsten, billigen Jumpscare in die Hose machen wird dieses Spiel eine massive Enttäuschung über alle Maßen sein. 

Gesamtwertung: 1/10, auch nur, weil mir der Mensch leid tut, der für den Sound verantwortlich ist. Denn der hat zumindest ein bisschen was drauf und ist für sein Leben damit gestraft, bei diesem Spiel mitgewirkt zu haben.

review:
Pineview Drive ist ein kein Spiel für schwache Nerven oder volle Blasen! Jeder Tag in dieser Villa spannt die Nerven weiter an; sind die Tage anfangs noch ein wenig mild und subtiler, wird es täglich schrecklicher.
Jeder Tag zwingt einen dazu weiter in die Gemäuer des Pineview anwesens vorzudringen und somit auch neuen Foltern für den Verstand.
Auch muss man das Angstsystem für sich entdecken, denn was genau als erschrecken gilt und was nicht, lässt das Spiel bewusst im Verborgenen. So kommt zusätzlich zum Schock auch noch etwas zusätzliche Schwierigkeit hinzu.
Spielenswert!

Wenn euch die Zusammenfassung nicht reicht, schaut doch in unser Let's Play:

author: {'steamid': '76561198046881950', 'num_games_owned': 625, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1496160023}
review: Наткнулся тут на один инди-хоррор Pineview Drive, эдакий симулятор особняка с привидениями. Вполне получилось атмосферно, и благодаря окружению и качественным звукам. Суть в том что-бы продержатся 30 дней в этом особняке и не сойти с ума. Здоровье тут в виде шкалы психической стабильности, которую понижает страх. Напоминает Knock-Knock только в 3D. Исследуя дом, на фоне тикают старинные часы, персонаж может спокойно потерять часть это шкалы, ибо пугает тут все: звук стягивающийся веревки, как будто кто то вешается, а потом тень висельника падающая от света свечей, шаги на этаже выше, внезапный "Псс" шепотом в темноте, детский плач на игральной площадке, качающаяся сама по себе качель, странная фигура у маяка, мебель сама по себе передвигается в разное расположении или вообще в кучу сваливается, затухающие свечки, кто-то выключает свет. Или например зашел в комнату, смотришь картину а на ней внезапно среди нарисованных деревьев какая-то мразь призрачная появляется и с воплем бросается на тебя. И потом же этот призрак стоит за дверью на улице и стучит действуя на нервы. И это малое что там происходит, только первые дни. Места которые можно посетить это сам огромный просто особняк с отличным окружением внутри, его кладбище, и вроде бы маяк. Все бесшовное, спокойной можно в любой момент выйти на улицу и пойти на кладбище среди ночи, только я очконул. из окон видно все что происходит на улице, а на улице через окна видно что происходит в особняке. В общем годно пока что все. Из минусов это движок юнити, поэтому оптимизация не самая лучшая, ну и иногда баги с освещением.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069667940', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1407894512}
review:
Играть можно только благодаря общей атмосфере. Подойдёт тем, кто любит хорроры в классических декорациях - с картинами, стариной мебелью, зеркалами в тяжёлых рамах, мраморными статуями и др. Pineview Drive играет на страхе перед темнотой и темными комнатами. Темнота здесь сопровождает большую часть игрового времени, в ходе игры постоянно возникает желание включать как можно больше света и зажигать свечи, чтобы не оставаться один на один перед лицом кромешной тьмы. Отдельно стоит похвалить звуковое сопровождение, мелодии умело поддерживают напряжение, а внезапные резкие звуки пугают не хуже скримеров, которые также пристутсвуют в игре. 
 Ожидал более развернутой истории, но она здесь достаточно куцая. Гемплей также однообразен, сводится к хождению из одной комнаты в другую и поиску новых дверных ключей.   
Итог: игра только для любителей жанра.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031826746', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 559, 'last_played': 1407502734}
review:
If you want to see it as a demo of a new horror game mechanism, Pineview Drive is great and could definitely be worth a try. If you're a veteran horror fan and will do anything for a few seconds of real in-game fear, I promise you that you'll get your scares in the first few hours--that alone might be worth the $15 price tag. But as a stand-alone game, judged against other indie horror games out there, Pineview Drive is probably not worth playing. The first few nail-biting days in the mansion had me really optimistic about what was coming next. But the tedious gameplay (plan to walk through pretty every room in the house, multiple times, every day, looking for keys or journal entries), the overused scares, and the lack of a compelling story quickly drained both fear and enjoyment from my experience. The developers themselves defend the lack of story, posting the following in the Steam forums:

[quote=aegsds]We are sorry, but this game don´t has a typical ending like "ok look this is the end of the story now and everything was clear from the beginning". The game wants you to come up with own ideas of what really happend.[/quote]

The problem with a philosophy like this is that it only makes sense if there is enough material in the game for the player to come up with their own version of events (think Home or even Gone Home). This haunted house has little personality of its own, and feels more like being in an amusement park ride than in an actual place with a history. For example, there was one random event that had my character trapped in a room full of clocks, and the ticking seemed to be driving him insane. All the clocks were set to 5:00. Did something happen at 5:00? Is that when I could have killed my wife, or when...something happened? No, it turns out that it was just another random scare, and the clocks were only set to 5:00 because that's where they stall at the end of each day. And I never did find out what my character had done or what happened to him. The events at the end of the game didn't reveal anything.

For an example in contrast: in haunted-house games like Amnesia (both Frictional's original and thechineseroom's sequel), not only is there a coherent story, there are general themes that add to your experience of the environments. Exploitation, torture, loss of children, surveillance, monstrous industry...the simple events of the game are darkly colored by the way your imagination slowly mulls over these ideas as you play. You won't find any deep story elements like that in Pineview Drive. The scary sound is just a scary sound, the scary doll is just a scary doll, and you can be scared or not be scared in the moment--but this isn't a game where you take the fear with you, a game that leaves you lying awake at night, unable to move on to pleasant dreams.

So much wasted potential in this game, which could have been something memorable with an overhaul of the key-hunting gameplay and some love from a writer who cares about telling a good story. I hope the developers learn from this experience and continue to work with their fear mechanic, because it does have a lot of potential. (However, it's also currently imbalanced, making the last day of the game almost impossible to complete.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198121494479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1407431109}
review:
My first impression of the game and its concept was good. It's rare that a game has made me jump in my seat more than once, and at least for me this game delivered that. At first I enjoyed the environment and didn't overly mind the game mechanics.

Unfortunately, there are a few negative aspects to the game that result in the kind of frustration that can make one give up and quit. I did just that, on day 14 in-game. I left when the game turned into "Door Unlocking in the Dark Simulator".	

1. The complete lack of lighting. Candlelight is useless in the corridors, as they don't light up more than a 2-foot radius. You can't see anything by them, their purpose is limited to a marker as a point of reference to run toward. The flashlight batteries don't last long enough, which was the deal-breaker that made me walk away as an unsatisfied customer. Once the flashlight runs out, it becomes physically impossible to progress in the game. I'm on a MacBook Pro Retina, and no combination of screen brightness or in-game brightness setting allows me to see even one foot in front of me. I'm literally locked in a black screen with no idea if I'm standing in front of a door or a wall. This ruined the entire game - the flashlight should be infinitely powered, simple as that. With the flashlight it's still dark enough to be spooky, but you can at least see where you're going.

2. Too many doors with no in-game tracking of what is going on. Not all gamers have great spacial awareness and the fantastic memory required to remember exactly which doors are still locked, let alone where every single door leads. Once the house really begins to open up around day 10, I completely lost all sense of the house's layout and the ability to navigate. You would think that running around the layout over and over again would ingrain the map in your mind, but at least for me this was not the case - it's just too much all at once to keep track of. Bare minimum, a door should be visibly marked as either locked or unlocked without having to try to open it. Even better, add an in-game map that shows the layout as well as the status of all doors.

3. I have never, ever - ever! - played a game where you had to permanently hold down a key on the keyboard in order to play. The character's walking speed is abysmal - it is mandatory to hold down SHIFT every second you play to get the character to "run" (aka, walk at a normal pace). There should at least be a setting to inverse the walk/run speeds (ie: option to make character fast by default, hold shift to walk).

4. Far too often, there is absolutely no clue given about where you should look next. You wander around the entire house checking nearly every room until your character finally gives in and states something like "I think I heard water running in the bathroom", when there was never an auditory cue of running water. Same for "noises from the chess room", and a few others. Overall, I think this game would have benefited a lot from a little more leading of the story, rather than expecting us to run around constantly looking for that "one thing" happening somewhere in the house. I think the developer probably considers this the "mystery" element to the game, having to hunt through every room over and over again. The problem is it isn't fun, and only serves to stretch out game play.

I'd say this game would be good for gamers who have unlimited patience, those who have never quit a game out of frustration after being expected to do the same thing over and over again with very little progress. You also need to be comfortable playing in a completely dark environment (not just dark, but pitch black), where the only visual aid you get is a red outline around actionable objects.

I wish I could praise this game for being clever and unique, but I paid $20 and made it less than halfway through the game. At that point, I ran out of flashlight batteries and was left with a game where I have a black screen and red outlines around doorknobs and candlesticks. Not my idea of a good time.

review:
Worum geht es? :
Das Spiel an sich ist vollkommen atmosphärisch aufgebaut und macht heidenspaß Nachts durch dieses riesen Haus zu streifen,wo hinter jeder Ecke ein Schockmoment auf dich warten könnte.
Natürlich macht man das alles nicht nur so sinnlos, man versucht herauszufinden was vor 30 Jahren mit Linda passiert ist und entdeckt Stück für Stück ein Teil seiner Vergangenheit.
Man versucht ganze 30 Tage am Stück zu überleben und Tag für Tag wird dies immer mehr zu einer Herausforderung. 
Also sollte man sich lieber zweimal überlegen ob man ein Raum wieder betreten möchte oder nicht.

Fazit:
Obwohl dieses Spiel relativ monoton erscheint ( meistens nur sich erkundigen und Schlüssel suchen ) , macht es durch die Atmosphäre wirklich sehr viel Spaß und für Horrorfans auf jedenfall eine Empfehlung wert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118539187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1407369890}
review:
A quite elaborate review for Pineview Drive, TL:DR at the bottom. Enjoy!

Pineview Drive provides an interesting approach on the whole horror scenario, although the setting is quite classic: 

There is this huge mansion, strange stuff is going on there, no one knows exactly what it is just that nobody survived longer than 30 days. And now it's up to you to enter the house, solve the mystery and stay alive until day 30 and beyond...

The MechaniX (minor spoilers!):
The biggest asset of Pineview Drive is, as you might already know, the 'Punished for Panic' mechanic, that actually works quite nice especially since it also provides a 'Reward for Relax' function. This means, the game will try to scare you, and the further you get into it, the more creative it gets. If you get scared or shocked, you will lose lifeforce (basically hitpoints) and the game turns the screw a little tighter on you. Playing in total darkness with a headphone is definitely not recommended for the faint hearted player. On the other hand, if you remain calm, you will slowly regenerate and your character will relax.

The PlayZ:
The gameplay revolves around finding keys, unlocking rooms and gathering small bits of information about the mystery engulfing this cursed building. Whenever you find another clue the game advances to the next day and saves your progress. Finding those keys can be quite time consuming and will require a lot of backtracking. A good sense of direction and orientation is more than helpful, since there will be no minimap to guide you. 

Apart from keys you will also find matches and batteries to help you, since you will be playing mostly at night, and the game provides a nice variety of light sources (see The TechniX). The game also offers a helpful clue-system that points you in the general direction whenever you are completely lost or running into the utterly wrong direction. These clues come in the form of your character dropping a line in the form of 'Didn't I xxxxx something in that xxxxx place?' and will help you finding the next objective. 

Keeping a watchful eye on your surroundings to actually find the objectives is up to you, of course, although objects are highlighted to make them easier to spot, once you are close.

The TechniX:
My first impression on the technical performance were slightly disappointing, since the game seems to have framerate issues due to its programming. Cranking all details up to max might result in a laggy performance, even if you sport a powerful system. Also the textures are not as High-Res as you might be used from other triple-A titles and some objects definitely look a bit cheaply designed. The overall graphic appearance is still solid, and I have seen Indie-Games that looked far worse (not counting the ones that actually want to have a 8/16-Bit look).

What the graphic engine does great is the light-sourcing! 
Since you will be surrounded by semi-darkness most of the game, the use of lightsources and options plays an important part in your gameplay. A single, bright source of light will cast extreme shadows, and I have oftend found myself in a situation, where a single flickering candle is rather emphasizing the darkness, then keeping it at bay. Sometimes the moonlight and weather-effects are more than enough light to get around, instead of using the lightswitch and plunging half a room  in pitchblack darkness.

So what about the audios?
This is where Pineview Drive really shines. From heavy breathing to creaking floortiles, the developers sure know how to use sound to make you feel uneasy! A creepy background soundtrack also helps to create the tensed athmosphere that empowers the basic 'don't get scared'-catch of the game.

And the controls?
Using the mouse to look around while moving with your standard WASD is something you should be used to, although I miss an option to rebind the keys and most of all an 'always run' option, since holding down the left shift-key for hours can be a pain in the ... especially since the movement without shift is dreadfully slow and rarely neccessary. There is also E to use/pickup stuff, F-lashlight on/off and R-eload batteries.

TL:DR - The ConclusionZ: 
Pineview Drive is a nice House of Horrors game, that focusses on athmosphere instead of throwing zombies and skeletons at you. Keeping calm in surprise-situations is key to surviving the 30 day plot that will take around 8-9 hours to beat. 

The graphic is not the finest and slightly Low-Res in places, although the lightsourcing and weather effects are solid work. Some optimization might be needed/patched to solve the framerate issues. Therefore the soundeffects are nice and scary.

Approx. 20€ at fullprice might be bit overpriced for some, but getting it on a steam-sale should be worth your money.

Hope this review helped you in your decision, feedback is much appreciated.
Don't get scared!
Shendril

author: {'steamid': '76561197963164050', 'num_games_owned': 999, 'num_reviews': 221, 'playtime_forever': 810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1433000201}
review:
This game reminds me of the windows labyrinth screensaver with some interactive elements included. Finding keys, finding doors, finding notes, finding batteries, finding matchsticks... that "game" is a pure searching simulator. Don't get fooled like me by the screenshots. After you're in the game it becomes night within a few minutes and after that, you stumble around in the darkness. On the pictures it looks like a nice and decent adventure. But there is NOTHING which really kept me interested in the story or what will happen next. After a few minutes most players (like me) will get so pissed off by searching the next key/note/door/whatever that they start running around and the atmosphere dies completly.

It wouldn't be so bad if there would be at least a pattern... something that makes any sense. But everything is scattered around at pure random. After you finally find the note (which are useless and give you nothing), the day ends and drags you out of the game and the next day is like the day before. You start again searching in every room, every corner until you finaly give up and the game gives you a clue, where to look. Great.

How the game determines wether you are scared or not is a pure joke. If you just slightly move your mouse during an event or you run, that guy freaks out and gets an heart attack. The prank only works, because you will get bored and don't even expect that anything will still happen at all. Even then you will be more surprised than scared.

The only really scarry thing about this game is, how shitty it looks and still chew up your hardware. If you really want to play it, buy it now, while it is on sale. But for 20 bucks? Forget it.


Besides, if you want to play a good horror adventure, try Scratches. That game works even at daylight and still gives me some shivers. Aaand it is also much cheaper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039430300', 'num_games_owned': 9468, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1407251627}
review:
Pineview Drive is an indie haunted house simulator with relatively simple gameplay. Over the span of 30 days, you try and find clues to what happened to your wife, Linda, who disappeared without a trace at an old abandoned estate 20 years ago, for your own closure. To accomplish this you must look around the house, find keys, open doors, and experience a variety of scares and spooks.

And let me restate this point: This game is a haunted house simulator. It's with these expectations that I think the game is best experienced. It's done in a similar vein to the Ju-On The Curse game or the Haunted House mode in the Fatal Frame 2 Wii Remake. Nothing is coming to attack you, there is no hiding mechanic, no enemies to shoot and kill. Your character is slow, can't jump, and gameplay consists of looking for keys/matches/batteries/notes/locked doors, and experiencing events.

On this accord, it does some smart things. Your character does have health even though you're not attacked directly, the health instead is basically responsive to how you react when 'scared' When a scare happens, if you do something with your controls, IE starts shaking your mouse around or suddenly start running or stop running or stop altogether, basically changing the pace of movement you were doing when the scare happens, you'll lose health. How much health you lose is accordant to how extreme/timely your reaction is. This also is all monitored to take note of what you react strongly too and don't and stores that information away to change some minor events. It works well for the most part, though I noticed the game seemingly thinking I was scared of certain events that didn't scare me.

And in my opinion the game works, mainly due to the fact the atmosphere of the game is good and some of the scares did legitimately scare the crap out of me. Scares are subjective, but most games don't scare me, so when one game manages to scare me a few times over the course of the game, I take notice. The atmosphere helps a lot towards this, the rooms look appropriately creepy, the music has good variety and can be good to make you unnerved, along with the type of music you sometimes question if the music is the background music or something happening. The game starts off rather slow with little happening, but escalates as the days go on.

Some scares and moments are obviously inspired by other things however. They're still effective, but can take away from the moment if you recognize the scare's obvious inspiration. Without spoiling too much, there were two scenes that were very obviously inspired by the film, "Ringu", and the game, "Condemned: Criminal Origins." And not all scares were winners, many either left me unphased and some were a bit silly.

On the flip-side, there was some very unique scares in places and some were handled well, and there's a good variety. There's even a few scares and entities that are randomized and can happen anywhere later in the game as you're exploring. Special mention from me goes to a certain clown and scarecrow...

But the game is bogged down by a few problems. Firstly, it's very dark. I had to turn brightness all the way up and it was still super dark. This would be fine, but you don't get your flashlight until a bit into the game, and I found myself stumbling through the dark for a while before I eventually found it. A second flaw is that while new elements get added in scares and the like, the gameplay remains mostly the same, making the later parts sometimes feel rather tedious. On this, in some of the later areas when a lot of the estate is opened up to you, sometimes there's very little indication of where you're supposed to go, leading you to randomly scout rooms to see if you spot any keys or if any events trigger. Spend too long searching, and your character will eventually tell you where to go, but it seems disappointing and not well designed especially since the game at some points does an excellent job at leading you to specific parts of the house with cues, sounds, and graphical things.

Also the last area of the game and the ending are slightly confusing and come out of left field, and I found the last area ended up being kind of trial and error with getting past it as it's a bit too harsh on your health and scares to get through all of it.

Still, it turned out better than I expected and I enjoyed playing it. It reminded me of a game version of those horror movies about characters stupidly staying at an obviously haunted house that gets worse as time goes on. Some good atmosphere and scares steal the show here, even if not all moments are winners. It's held back by a few problems, but if you want a haunted house simulator to play through, this is a pretty solid effort.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018138823', 'num_games_owned': 365, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1407073020}
review:
[b]About The Game:[/b]
Pineview Drive is a game that is designed to be a story driven thriller, it's designed to make you think that something isn't quite right and that if you round the next corner something may jump out at you. In most cases this is correct & every door is a new gateway into hell.

While this game is designed on Horror there's nothing in it that can physically hurt your character, there is only mental tricks that can end the game & in a majority of those cases the game pulls this off quite well with its sharp and shrill audio tones, it's nice graphics during the day and night & many other things that this game did well to capture the immersion.

It's a rather enjoyable experience & it's also quite a long experience with 30 days to play through & each of those days becomes a little more intense.

[b]The Review:[/b]
Pineview Drive is a well paced & well designed peice of Software that performs nicely & manages to capture you with it's good horror designs but it's story is pretty average. 

There are so many things that were good and bad about this game but where to start?

For starters i think we should get the story out of the road.

[b]The Story:[/b]
The Story has you (the main character) attempting to figure out what happened to your wife and why she went missing at the Mansion. 

Maybe it was something i missed or maybe because by the end of the game things felt a bit meh & i stopped caring so much but i was still left not understanding what the hell happened to her. All i got was a cinematic of you holding something and her running away into the forest, is this supposed to explain to me what happened? Cause it's done a bad job explaining.

Overall the story is pretty poor, but what about the rest of the game?

[b]The Gameplay:[/b]
The gameplay of this game is very similar to other Horror games you are required to find different keys and items to help you progress in the game, but here's where things change a bit unlike general Horror Games this one doesn't rely on monsters to scare you it rely's on your reactions to random noises or ghostly figures to do the damage rather than a monster chasing you down the corridor and needing to hide.

Although this mechanic is good and worked well, this game really needed more to it rather than just reaction avoidance. Most of the time i'd rather have reacted to the thing that made the noise and relied on it to scare me rather than "oh something made a noise better not look or it'll cause me to lose sanity". They could have REALLY done something great here and instead of just losing health with no signs of what caused it, they could used these ques to generate a random Ghost or something of that nature to terrify the player. (Really disappointed about that).

The dark atmosphere in this game is superb but it was lacking a few things here and there that could've made the game better, the more you played the game the more obvious it become that things weren't going to change up much after the power goes out and you have to rely on the Flashlight or Matches to light candles. This would have been PERFECT if and only IF you used the power outage much later in the game when things started to get more scary.

One thing this game did pretty nicely was the fact that it made sure you didn't miss the bigger scares because every night you had to find the biggest scares to progress further and collect the valuable keys you needed to open locked doors and find the diary entries. (Good Idea!)

[b]The Good:[/b]
This game had potential to be something more and sometimes it showed like the new feature of using just scares to make you go insane rather than using a random monster.

Or it's unique idea of not just relying on jump scares all the time but actually making sure you're getting scared by forcing you to endure them to find the keys.

Using a pretty normal setting not like most settings and making it creepy with atmosphere and not just a run down old building.

[b]The Bad:[/b]
Not branching out much and after a while things got pretty repeatative, not enough variation with the scares.

Around about the last 5 days things seemed to start being rushed it took maby a minute to complete them from 25 - 29, 3 of the days from 26 - 29 involved finding a peice of photo with absolutely no new scares to endure between finding them? Come on seriously it's meant to be a horror game not a find and seek game.

Removing players use of interactive light switches too early in the game to increase the scare factor before things actually started to get scary, it would have been better removed after the scary stuff really began around day 15 or so.

No clues as to where you are supposed to go or what you're meant to be doing until the clock reaches 5:00AM it really doesn't help, try adding a quick vocal que to the beginning giving the player just a little hint as to what they should be doing.

It changed from day to night really quickly, like 2 minutes of day and about 20 minutes of night or so, and once you reach a certain point in time at about 5:00AM ingame time the clock just stops, you really could have used this feature much better and made it a time limit, if you missedthe deadline then you miss part of the story and won't get the full picture of what happened.

[b]The Verdict:[/b]
Although i did enjoy the experience of this game it's going to receive a very low score because there was just so much more i expected from this and didn't end up receiving it.

I give this game a 5/10 because while it brought something new and interesting to try & experience there was just too late here to warrent anything more than a 5.

There was scares, i did jump a few times but more often than not i ended up just walking around going "Oh was that meant to be scary?" As i said earlier in the review instead of expecting people to not react to the games scares you should have expected them to react and then used this to generate a more terrifying experience.

While the game had beautiful graphics for the most part, it was a bit lacking in other parts the lighting and the atmosphere during the night was great & the transition between day and night was beautiful to watch.

[b]Do I Recommend This Game?:[/b]
I find it hard to recommend this game due to the fact that there was just so many things that could have been there to make it a more enjoyable experience but for the most part it was just lacking in things to make it scary.

If you think you'll enjoy it then give it a go but don't expect much unless you're easily scared.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046664981', 'num_games_owned': 878, 'num_reviews': 267, 'playtime_forever': 118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1407032471}
review:
Pineview Drive es un juego con buenas ideas y ambientación, pero mal llevado en su ejecución. El juego nos reta a superar 30 días en una mansión muy tétrica mientras tratamos de desentrañar los misterios que se ocultan tras la desaparición de nuestra esposa en ese lugar 20 años atrás. Sin duda un punto de partida muy potente que se ve absolutamente lastrado por las mecánicas jugables. Y esque todo se resume en una cosa: Encuentra llaves para abrir puertas.

A los 30 minutos de juego ya habrás visto todo lo que jugablemente esconde Pineview Drive, tornándose rápidamente en una experiencia aburrida e incluso frustrante por momentos, puesto que además de tener que repetir una y otra vez el proceso de buscar llaves para abrir puertas (que ni te indican qué puerta abre cada llave), encima tendrás que encender la luces una y otra vez, por el simple hecho de que de un día para otro (dentro del juego,claro) todo vuelve a estar en su lugar, todas las luces y velas que hubieras encendido volverán a estar apagas, obligándote a repetir los mismos procesos una y otra vez.

En cuanto al apartado del terror, también te deja la sensación de que podrían haber aprovechado muchísimo más un entorno tan sugerente como el de esta mansión (muy bien diseñada, eso sí). Es cierto que en los primeros compases de juego, vas literalmente acojonado, cuando no sabes con qué tipo de cosas vas a encontrarte, pero pronto descubres que si eres un avezado en los juegos de terror y has jugado a títulos como el primer Amnesia, este Pineview Drive es algo muy light... Demasiado light.

Para terminar su alto precio tampoco ayuda mucho. En resumen, puede ser un juego un poco interesante si lo conseguís a un precio bastante inferior al que tiene ahora mismo, aunque avisados quedáis de que tiene unas mecánicas jugables pobres y el terror que puede producir el título es casi irrisorio. Un pena :(

[b]NOTA: 4/10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198034150055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1407036752}
review:
Summary (TL;DR): The game is OK. It will (probably) scare you and give you the feeling a horror game should. But if you’re in for a storyline or interesting/innovative gameplay then you’re going to be disappointed with the game.

So I just finished playing this game, so my opinion might be heavily influenced by how the game ended. I will try not to spoil anything in the opener, and talk about the game mechanics first.

Sound: So at first the sound in the game is alright, the music is there to creep you out and create an atmosphere. However, the music is constantly there and it feels out of place at most times.  At times, the music will get intense as well, and loud noises will come out of nowhere, which again feels out of place most of the time and is overused in my opinion. There are a lot of sounds that are there to disturb you, example at times you’ll hear footsteps near you, or someone “Psst”-ing. Personally I don’t think these are out of place and makes sense to use, and they aren’t really overused to the point where they become an annoyance

Graphics: Graphics were okay, I don’t have anything to add to this since I didn’t really expect AAA game graphics in the first place. Some textures were weird, but it’s nothing to really focus on.

Gameplay: Gameplay wasn’t that interesting. Opening the same doors to the same rooms every day, trying to find out which room is going to have any “Action” or events happening in them is not as interesting as it may sound. It was alright the first couple of days when there weren’t that many rooms to look through, but once you unlock almost every door it gets irritating to put up with, because the game basically requires that you re-visit every room every day. If you run around confused for a prolonged time, the person you’re controlling will give you a clue, which is nice, but I still feel like it’s annoying that you have to walk around every room all the time.

Level-design: The level design isn’t TOO bad, but it does fall short on some parts. Some rooms connect weirdly, though it does help you getting around the house easily once you have all the doors opened. Still, it’s an annoyance walking around, and you will often find yourself being lost in all the rooms that you can visit, and will probably miss some every now and then. That being said, the rooms were nicely decorated and they helped with the atmosphere.

Atmosphere: So I guess we can all agree that atmosphere is the most important thing in a horror game, and Pineview does get away with it pretty nicely I’d say. There are the annoyingly repetitive sounds I mentioned earlier, but if you look past that, the game does succeed in having that horror feel to it. Some of the props helped nicely and were put to good use. Overall I’d say that Pineview does capture a good scary atmosphere and there’s not a lot to really touch on here.

Story [b][No spoilers][/b]: So I decided to split this up in to two, because the story annoys me to no end. It starts off by the main person arriving to the house where some stuff has gone down. Linda, the wife I’m assuming, has died in the house and “No one has survived in the house for 30 days” and you have to find out what happened to Linda. Simple stuff, though from there the story kind of falls short, and I can’t go in to detail without spoiling the game, but you basically find letters scattered around the house that tells you what has been going on in the house back when the incident with Linda happened. That’s it, that’s the basic storyline.

Story [b][SPOILERS][/b]: Right, so moving on, this is where the game falls short and REALLY disappoints me. Note that this section will spoil the entire “Surprise” of the game, so read with caution. During the game you find some notes which help you finding out what happened to Linda, and you find notes explaining what has been going on around the house, like the clown being moved around and then appearing in its original place, and that Linda had been hearing strange noises in the house. Though, the notes doesn’t seem to tell all that much until you start gathering the pieces of a picture, which then reminds the main person about a doll. A doll that is evil, and, assumingly, is buried with Linda. On day 29 you gain access to the cemetery, and enter Linda’s tomb, and in that tomb you’re going to face the game’s biggest disappointment. You’d expect everything to be cleared up, an open ending, or some sort of explanation as to why the house is being haunted, why the clown is moving around, why the scarecrow will chase you, why the shadows of the girls appear at random times or get to know something about Linda’s death. But no. The game ends weirdly, abruptly and in a very strange fashion. As you walk in Linda’s tomb you suddenly find a machine. There’s no explanation as to what this machine does, and you have to turn it on. Once you do, the game ends with a video which I assume is a continued version of the video in the very beginning of the game. This still clears nothing at all, and the machine still feels weirdly out of place.

Edit: This is the first time I have actually taken my time to write a lenghty review for a game, and I would love some feedback. Thanks in advance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030679415', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1511044704}
review:
non posso, in tutta onestà, consigliare questo gioco,
partiamo dal comparto tecnico, il motore grafico, unity 3d, ormai standard nelle produzioni indie, in questo gioco è ottimizzato in maniera catastrofica, una media di framerate di 20 x secondo con dettagli bassi e bassa risoluzione, non solo inguardabile ma ingiocabile, su un pc che regge benissimo il red engine di the witcher 2, tutto questo perchè l' intero livello viene caricato in memoria saturando la scheda video, e caricato inutilmente di lavoro la gpu .
mai visto una schifezza del genere, in termini di prestazioni, con l' unity 3d, lasciatemelo dire.
passiamo al gameplay, semplicemente il gioco non riesce a catturare, le premesse sono buone, ma non si fa altro che passare il tempo ad aprire porte e accendere candele.
un buon simulatore di casa abbandonata, nessun file da consultare, nessuno "spavento" l' unica paura è quella di aver buttato via i soldi, e l' avviso iniziale di non giocare se si hanno problemi di cuore, suona sempre di più come una presa per il culo.
altra scelta ridicola dal punto di vista del gameplay...
la torchia elettrica... non è disponibile da subito, ma dovrete cercarla e vi assicuro che ci vorrà parecchio a trovala, vorrei propio legare gli sviluppatori ad una sedia e fargli giocare ad unreal tournament per 30 minuti senza un arma, cosi, tanto per fargli capire che certe cose servono fin dall' inizio, e che certe giochi vanno programmati usando il cervello e che non serve fare gli originali a tutti i costi...
una schifezza videoludica senza precedenti, male orchestrata, male ottimizzata. estremamente noiosa e poco attraente.
mi fa rabbia vedere che sta cosa ha più feedback di un ottimo lavoro come è Anna EE.
non buttate via i vostri soldi.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027755087', 'num_games_owned': 428, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1406872426}
review:
tl;dr: Game is poorly optomized, laggy, and the scare mechanic is broken. Good atmophere, doesnt save the game though.


I was super excited to play the game, but quickly realized that it's almost unplayable.
It's so badly optomized, I have to play with all the settings on low. Even with that, it was extremely laggy and choppy.
The graphics kept wigging out. There was so much texture tearing and glitchy shadows, but that might be because I had to play with PS2 graphics. Also, it might have had to do with the low settings, but everything was pitch black in the dark. As in, I couldnt see shit, even if lighting nearby. I truend up the brightness, but nothing. I understand a games need to be dark, but this was blindness in a room that had both lights on and candles lit. I had to watch through my stream to see what I was doing. 

I'll give it credit, the game is very atmospheric. Too bad I couldnt see what was scaring me.
That leads me to another thing. Your health goes down for no reason. I assumed the game based the health going down by your reaction, like mouse shittering or camera flinging or backing away or even not moving. Instead, it just randomly decides when to reduce your health. I feel like I'm playing IllBleed. I wish I was playing IllBleed instead of this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968746776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1406904789}
review:
Zu Anfang war ich begeistert wegen der wirklich gruselig, einsamen Atmosphere...
Hauptaufgabe istes, Schlüssel für etliche verschlossene Türen zu finden...und das sind einige!

Man findet einen Schlüssel; Versucht zu erinnern welche Türen noch zu sind und sucht sich den Wolf,
bis man sie endlich gefunden hat. Jeder Tag endet mit dem Fund eines Schriftstückes.
dann verliest der Sprecher ein bis 2 Sätze und der nächste Tag beginnt...

Und immer wieder wacht man im gleichen Zimmer auf! Also wieder latschen und verschlossene 
Türen checken. 

Das ist eigentlich der ganze Inhalt des Spiels. Man kann Schalter für Licht an/ausschalten, Türen aufschliessen
und ganz selten mal ein Gimmick (Fernbedienung TV, Tröte) ohne Funktion für den Spielablauf anklicken.

Gruseleffekte sind ganz nett. Da ich aber genervt war wegen der ewigen von vorne beginnenden Suche
(Karte gibts nicht!) nach Türen haben die meisten "Erschrecker"mich kalt gelassen.

Ich habe jetzt bei Tag 8 aufgehört, weil ich ohne erkennbaren Grund vor Angst gestorben bin, als ich ein
Badezimmer betreten habe, wo nichts zu sehen war, vor dem man sich in Acht nehmen sollte.

Fazit: Für zwischendurch ganz nett. Muss man aber nicht haben.
Mehr als 10€ sollte man hier nicht investieren.

review: Für fünf €uro wäre das Spiel Preis - / Leistungstechnisch gut gewesen. Es ist gruselig aber auch recht billig und dumm: "Wie komme ich durch die Tür? Oh, davor liegt ja ein Schlüssel. Und wie komme ich durch diese Tür? Oh da liegt auch ein Schlüssel neben. Und hier ist ja noch einer. Da ich nicht weiter komme sollte ich versuchen eine der 'tausend' abgeschlossenen Türen damit zu öffnen..." Das Spiel ist letztlich sehr irreal (den Horror natürlich ausgeklammert) und banal. Die Grafik ist auch nicht ansprechend. Ich empfehle daher, sich vor dem Kauf ein Gameplayvideo anzusehen. Wer keine Einwände dabei entdeckt, dem sei der Kauf gerne ans Herz gelegt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079724187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1406901183}
review: I tried to make it through this game in the interest of being open minded and writing a fair review, but it was so mind bogglingly dull I just couldn't take it anymore. The atmosphere and darkness are indeed creepy but the pacing was terrible, and the scares were so laughably unfrightening, few, and far between that it felt like a poor reward for all the aimless circling ( done at a snails pace walk ) to obtain them. I don't mind a slow start but this went on with no clear rise in the pace of activity for 10 agonizingly slow levels. I felt more annoyed than anything as I made my nightly rounds, hoping against hope to stumble across the door behind which something would finally happen quickly. The story is delivered in single sentences and is, so far, too vague and without unity to be engaging. Yeah, yeah, some creepy stuff happened, but there's no character or conflict or mystery or anything motivating me to find out what happens next. If you don't have action or puzzles you have to have a really good story. A game can't sustain interest on atmosphere alone. Perhaps all of these things improve later in the game, but without some kind of hook in the first few levels that teases at something  mysterious or surprising or scary or dramatic etc. I have to presume after 10 levels without change that this is what I can expect from the rest of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996719241', 'num_games_owned': 1048, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1406758564}
review:
Here's my initial first look Let's Play. TL;DR and in-depth thoughts underneath:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KQqGzf2vF4Y

TL;DR: It's a good game made for the most part by just two people. The lighting and sounds are great and definitely atmospheric. The graphics are good but it is a big game made in Unity, so the limitations of the engine does mean it can lag a bit but it's not too bad at all. Gameplay is simple as it revolves around finding things and exploring the place, but the experience is there and can get very tense. Would recommend.

More in-depth:

The gameplay so far seems to be based around finding keys to unlock doors, with rooms that have things in them that pertain to the story. There are a number of things to interact with including candles and light switches, and things to find like keys. The house actually seems quite large and I've only gone into a small part of it so far, so I imagine key finding plays an integral part in the exploration of the game. This is a bit of pain though as sometimes it can be easy to miss the key so you will have to take a good look around in each place you visit otherwise you will be walking around back and forth for ages in frustration wondering why the story isn't advancing and trying to find where the damn key is (Look low AND high!). It's hard to say how much of the game has changed for me based on my moves and reactions as mentioned in the features list but I have noticed things such as furnature being different when I go back to visit a room again, things get added or removed etc all based on what seems to be where else you've been during the level. I do feel like there isn't too much option to stray from the storyline though as keys for doors can appear at any point on any level. This does mean going back and forth as you will have to revisit an old room in order to find something new to advance.

I think the graphics are what you'd expect from your average horror title. Textures are pretty good, and the models have fair amounts of detail when needed and nothing looks too low poly or low res. As for things such as lighting in the game: When it's night time and you are in a dark room with the candles on, it does create quite an interesting atmosphere. These lights are surprisingly weak however, and often aren't enough to fill the room so even at night with the lights on you will find it to be VERY dark. This makes it very difficult to play in a lit room at certain points, and is one of the reasons why I found it hard to spot items sometimes. Maybe that's intentional and will force you to play in a darkened room, though. I imagine that would only heighten the effect of horror. If you're using a flashlight, the huge shadows you cast can actually make you jump if you happen to catch the cornice and it casts a huge shadow you weren't expecting! One negative about the graphics is that I don't feel it's very well optimised. My framerate can go from 60 to 15 purely from turning around and looking at certain things. 
The other quip I have about the graphics is the door animation. They often open towards you and go through you, which is rather disconcerting. This does seem to be a sign of a UIG game though. They are yet to figure out how doors should work in a game.

The sounds in the game seem very fitting and add to the atmosphere and help to build tension and fear. Lots of tense ambient sounds, momentus music, things like breathing, which I assume is coming from the character you're playing, and things like wood creaking and even one sound that sounds like someone walking around in leather trousers, which is rather odd. I have come across a couple of things that made me jump. The screen flashed white and there was a sudden noise, although I won't say from what to spoil the game. The way momentum builds from the sounds really set you up in anticipation of a sudden noise or something, and it definitely got my heart racing. At the very start of the game there is a health warning suggesting you should avoid the game if you have a known heart and/or circulator disease, or if you're a pregnant women, which seems reasonable enough for any horror game really and not just this one. There is also narration in this game (I believe in both English and German) that narrates a story when you reach certain parts.


Whilst this review is purely based on my first impressions, it does make me want to play on to see what else is in store as it does seem like it's been well thought out. I do have a slight bit of concern for the fact the whole game is revolved around one house, wondering if maybe you could get bored of your environment before long, but as there were a lot of rooms left for me to explore in different parts of the mansion I think it should be fine and fit in with the story well. The relatively low graphics optmization that gave me some moments of low framerates is another cause for concern but I imagine if you just turn down the graphics a bit you should be okay. It was still playable for me but having a smoother framerate would have been nicer. Either way, if you're into your horror games I'd definitely say to give a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963359405', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1408039288}
review:
Review Pineview Drive

Pineview Drive ist ein Horror/Schocker Spiel der besonderen Art. Es erkennt ob sich der Spieler erschreckt. Und es funktioniert. Sehr cool. 
Das Game spielt in einer verlassenen Villa. Wir müssen dort 30 Tage überleben. Wie das funktioniert könnt ihr im LP sehen.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HoSXaSoMHVc

Die Schockeffekte kommen sehr gut rüber, da sie von einer grandiosen Klangkulisse unterstützt werden. Ich habe mich nicht nur einmal erschrocken.
Das einzige was ich bis jetzt Negatives sagen kann, ist das es ab und zu etwas unübersichtlich wird wo es nun weiter geht.

Dann wie immer eine Pos/Neg Liste:

Positiv:
- Sehr gruselige bedrückende Atmosphäre 
- Gute Schockeffekt
- Grandiose Klangkulisse
- Grafik ist Ok
- Was braucht ein Horror Spiel mehr?

Negativ:
- Etwas langatmig teilweise
- manchmal weis man nicht weiter und muss auf die Tipps des Protagonisten warten ("Ich solle mich vielleicht nochmal bei der Schaukel umschauen) 

Alles in allem ein gutes Horror/Schocker Spiel was einen Stunden an den Pc zu fesseln weis. 

DerBurns
